name: Copy, transform and combine
description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

key_work.title: You will see me
key_work.creator_credit: Conor Bateman, Field Carr and Sari Braithwaite
key_work.brief_description: You will see me explores the way artists and amateurs alike have turned the camera on themselves since they became more accessible in the mid-20th century, and how this tradition is continued, amplified and tranformed through reality TV, the internet and social media.

constellations_primary.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_primary.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

start.title: You will see me
start.creator_credit: Conor Bateman, Field Carr and Sari Braithwaite
start.brief_description: You will see me explores the way artists and amateurs alike have turned the camera on themselves since they became more accessible in the mid-20th century, and how this tradition is continued, amplified and tranformed through reality TV, the internet and social media.

constellations_primary.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_primary.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

end.title: Spotlighting change
end.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
end.brief_description: Women have used the spotlight to push for change and defy industry expectations, both on and off the screen.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

links.description: The ‘Spotlighting change’ video in Goddess uses archival footage from awards ceremonies, press interviews and social media to comment on women’s on-screen representation.

start.title: TERROR NULLIUS
start.material_description: Single channel video, projection, colour and audio
start.brief_description: Part political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a political revenge fable that binds together a documentary impulse with speculative muckraking.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

end.title: Love Is the Message, the Message Is Death
end.brief_description: Love Is the Message, The Message Is Death reflects Jafa’s desire to craft a “black cinema” that is responsive to the “existential, political, and spiritual dimensions” of Black life, comprised of found footage sampled from films, newscasts, sporting events, music videos, and citizen videos.

constellations_other.name: Now watch this
constellations_other.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

links.description: Arthur Jafa’s first foray into visual art, Love is the message, the message is Death (2016), achieved critical acclaim and crystallised the collective experience of black America through a similar use of montage and mash-up of found footage, home movies and pop culture.

start.title: Love Is the Message, the Message Is Death
start.brief_description: Love Is the Message, The Message Is Death reflects Jafa’s desire to craft a “black cinema” that is responsive to the “existential, political, and spiritual dimensions” of Black life, comprised of found footage sampled from films, newscasts, sporting events, music videos, and citizen videos.

constellations_other.name: Now watch this
constellations_other.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

end.title: HyperNormalisation
end.creator_credit: Adam Curtis, Sandra Gorel and BBC
end.brief_description: HyperNormalisation is a 2016 BBC documentary by British filmmaker Adam Curtis. It argues that governments, financiers, and technological utopians have, since the 1970s, given up on the complex “real world” and built a simpler “fake world” run by corporations and kept stable by politicians.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

links.description: Compiled from archival footage, accompanied with voiceover by director Adam Curtis, HyperNormalisation (2016) also uses montage to explore corporatisation, conspiracy theories and cyberspace in the modern world.

start.title: [CENSORED]
start.creator_credit: Sari Braithwaite, Chloé Brugalé and Arenamedia
start.brief_description: An essay film by filmmaker and archivist Sari Braithwaite, [Censored] offers an overview of film censorship in Australia, told through an ever-changing collage of images compiled from the footage that was cut from films released domestically between 1958 and 1971.

constellations_other.name: Controversy and censorship
constellations_other.description: In this constellation, we look at the history of censorship in moving image history, from early blaxploitation films to videogames and beyond.

constellations_other.name: My Hometown: Archives woven into new narrative
constellations_other.description: Offering viewers a snapshot of life on the road for an Australian touring band in the 1960s, 'My Hometown', directed by Sari Braithwaite was developed reimagining archival 8mm footage shot by drummer Leon Isackson.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

end.title: TERROR NULLIUS
end.material_description: Single channel video, projection, colour and audio
end.brief_description: Part political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a political revenge fable that binds together a documentary impulse with speculative muckraking.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

links.description: Artist duo Soda_Jerk’s controversial TERROR NULLIUS (2018) also mines Australian cinematic history to create a mash-up of scenes that offer a searing critique of Australia’s systemic racism and refugee policy, which was built on the lie of terra nullius.

start.title: You will see me
start.creator_credit: Conor Bateman, Field Carr and Sari Braithwaite
start.brief_description: You will see me explores the way artists and amateurs alike have turned the camera on themselves since they became more accessible in the mid-20th century, and how this tradition is continued, amplified and tranformed through reality TV, the internet and social media.

constellations_primary.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_primary.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

end.title: [CENSORED]
end.creator_credit: Sari Braithwaite, Chloé Brugalé and Arenamedia
end.brief_description: An essay film by filmmaker and archivist Sari Braithwaite, [Censored] offers an overview of film censorship in Australia, told through an ever-changing collage of images compiled from the footage that was cut from films released domestically between 1958 and 1971.

constellations_other.name: Controversy and censorship
constellations_other.description: In this constellation, we look at the history of censorship in moving image history, from early blaxploitation films to videogames and beyond.

constellations_other.name: My Hometown: Archives woven into new narrative
constellations_other.description: Offering viewers a snapshot of life on the road for an Australian touring band in the 1960s, 'My Hometown', directed by Sari Braithwaite was developed reimagining archival 8mm footage shot by drummer Leon Isackson.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

links.description: You will see me creator Sari Braithwaite directed the visual essay film [CENSORED] (2018), compiling a montage of clips removed from feature films by Australian censors between 1951 and 1978.

start.title: HyperNormalisation
start.creator_credit: Adam Curtis, Sandra Gorel and BBC
start.brief_description: HyperNormalisation is a 2016 BBC documentary by British filmmaker Adam Curtis. It argues that governments, financiers, and technological utopians have, since the 1970s, given up on the complex “real world” and built a simpler “fake world” run by corporations and kept stable by politicians.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

end.title: Testify
end.brief_description: ‘Testify’ is a song by American rock band Rage Against the Machine and the third single from their third album The Battle of Los Angeles.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

links.description: Michael Moore’s music video for Rage Against the Machine’s ‘Testify’ (2000) features clips of then presidential candidates George W Bush and Al Gore, spliced together with found footage of modern industrialisation, cities and conflicts in a style reminiscent of the one HyperNormalisation would adopt years later.

start.title: Spotlighting change
start.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
start.brief_description: Women have used the spotlight to push for change and defy industry expectations, both on and off the screen.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

end.title: In her words
end.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
end.brief_description: By sampling talk shows, movies, acceptance speeches and interviews, Chiara Costanza has created a soundscape that features stars across time declaring, in one voice, that women be heard, not just admired.

constellations_primary.name: Speaking for herself
constellations_primary.description: This constellation traces some critical ways that women have used the moving image as a way of speaking truth to power.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

links.description: ‘Spotlighting change’ features many of the same women and ideas that visitors to Goddess can hear in the beginning of the exhibition, reflecting on their experiences.

start.title: In her words
start.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
start.brief_description: By sampling talk shows, movies, acceptance speeches and interviews, Chiara Costanza has created a soundscape that features stars across time declaring, in one voice, that women be heard, not just admired.

constellations_primary.name: Speaking for herself
constellations_primary.description: This constellation traces some critical ways that women have used the moving image as a way of speaking truth to power.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

end.title: Walk out with a goddess
end.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
end.brief_description: When the iconic characters in Goddess walk away, it’s an act of defiance – not surrender. These women are in dialogue, backing each other and backing themselves. When they walk away, they’re transformed. “Goodbye” is a new beginning, slamming a door is taking a stand.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

links.description: ‘In her words’ is an audio experience that welcomes visitors to Goddess, it is bookended by the related work ‘Walk out with a goddess’.
